text: [Music]
Lincoln was an in extremely thoughtful,
literate person. Now, he only had one
year of formal schooling in his entire
life, which makes you wonder if
education is even needed. He was
completely self-educated. And yet he
developed a remarkable command of the
English language. His letters, his
speeches are brilliantly
crafted. Um, and he wrote them all
himself. He didn't have a bunch of staff
speech writers like we do nowadays. He
didn't have spinmen going out and
telling the press what he was really
saying. Um, so yes, and this was, you
know, the Lincoln Douglas debates in
uh, were a period of a, you know, were a
product of a different era.
They weren't debates like we see on TV
nowadays with some no offense,
from the media, uh, asking stupid
questions and pressing the candidates to
attack each other. In the Lincoln
Douglas debate, one candidate, Stephen
A. Douglas, who was the senator,
Lincoln, who was running against him for
Senate in Illinois, one of them would
get up and give an hour and a half
speech. Then the other would get up and
give an hour speech responding, or maybe
it's the other way around. an hour
speech, an hour and a half speech
responding and then the first guy would
have half an hour to respond. This
required an audience with great
fortitude. How many people today are
going to listen to three or four hours
of speeches by Senate candidates? Not
very much. But thousands of people went
and listened to these. This was a
different era of politics. It was a time
when people were used to logical and um
you know long explanations of political
events. You didn't of political ideas.
you didn't just have little sound bites,
you know. Um, so yes, our politics today
is much less literate than it was. And
we don't have anybody, I don't think,
Democrat or Republican, with the
brilliant command of the language that
that Lincoln managed to achieve.
